docs.lead_paragraph: It all started in a barbershop in the Bronx. Between the bustle of four chairs, a Ms. Pac-Man machine and the Spanish soap operas on the little television, prosecutors said, two owners of the barbershop, one of them a former police officer, came up with a way to be paid for automobile accidents that had never happened. Over two years, prosecutors said yesterday, the scheme grew to include four police officers and a dozen civilians, who filed claims for necks and backs that had never been sprained, for chassis that had not been bent. They cheated seven insurance companies out of almost $230,000, the authorities said, by filing the fake reports and sending the supposed drivers to medical clinics pretending they had been hurt.

headline.main: Fraud Didn't Enrich Officers, Authorities Say

docs.abstract: Former and current police officers and number of civilians who tried to defraud insurance companies out of $230,000 by filing false accident claims only made about $1,000 each over two years, making crime they hatched at Bronx (NYC) barbershop relatively unprofitable; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A federal appeals panel yesterday upheld the conviction of a Manhattan obstetrician for defrauding insurance companies. The doctor, Niels H. Lauersen, based his appeal primarily on objections that the trial judge owned stock in one of the insurance companies, court papers said. But the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit found that the trial judge followed proper procedure and that his disqualification was not required. Dr. Lauersen had billed companies for gynecological procedures that were covered by his patients' policies to hide the uncovered fertility procedures he was performing. Susan Saulny (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fraud Conviction Upheld

docs.abstract: Federal appeals court upholds conviction of Manhattan obstetrician Dr Niels H Lauersen for insurance fraud (S)

byline.original: By Susan Saulny (NYT); Compiled by Anthony Ramirez

docs.lead_paragraph: The Westchester County executive, Andrew J. Spano, will announce a budget today that calls for laying off 236 employees in an effort to close an estimated shortfall of more than $100 million in the county's $1.4 billion budget. The layoffs, most of which will come in the Social Services and Health Departments, were the only way the county could avoid a tax increase of nearly 30 percent, Mr. Spano said. ''We have to cut right to the bone,'' Mr. Spano said. Even with the job cuts the county will face a large property tax increase, Mr. Spano said in an interview yesterday, but he said he planned to present options to the County Legislature that would further reduce the increase.

headline.main: Budget Gap In Westchester To Force 236 Layoffs

docs.abstract: Westchester County (NY) Executive Andrew J Spano will announce budget that will require layoff of 236 county employees; cuts will primarily effect Social Services and Health Departments, to close $100 million budget gap (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After months of grueling work, House and Senate negotiators said on Thursday that they had been unable to agree on three big issues in a bill to revamp Medicare and provide prescription drug benefits to the elderly. They said they would send the issues to the Senate majority leader, Bill Frist of Tennessee, and the speaker of the House, J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois, for decisions.

headline.main: 3 Big Issues Stump Negotiators In a Bill to Revamp Medicare

docs.abstract: House and Senate negotiators announce, after months of grueling work on Medicare bill, that they are bogged down on key issues of requiring traditional program to compete with private plans, limiting growth of spending and authorizing new tax-preferred savings accounts for medical expenses (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: What are we going to do about Medicare? That should be the subject of an open national debate. But right now Congressional leaders are trying to settle the question by stealth, with legislation that purports to be doing something else. An aging population and rising medical costs will eventually require the nation to provide Medicare with more money or to cut benefits, or both. Meanwhile, there are demands for a new benefit: a gradual shift away from hospital treatment and toward the use of drugs has turned the program's failure to cover prescription drugs into a gaping hole.
docs.abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column calls Medicare bill under discussion in Congress a Trojan horse; says Republican politicians are using bill that would finally provide retirees with prescription drug coverage to smuggle in provisions that could undermine Medicare; notes one provisions under consideration would limit Medicare's use of general revenue, while another would force Medicare to compete with private insurers; says Democrats who understand exactly what is going on, such as Sen Ted Kennedy, are adamantly opposed to bill; says Republicans have retreated a bit, but bill is still a Trojan horse (M)
docs.snippet: What are we going to do about Medicare? That should be the subject of an open national debate. But right now Congressional leaders are trying to settle the question by stealth, with legislation that purports to be doing something else.    An aging...

docs.lead_paragraph: Tayshah Armstrong met Bernard Vickers when she was barely 20 years old. Her first impression: they were an unlikely match. He was older, 29, shorter and bigger than the guys she usually went out with, said Ms. Armstrong, now 28. Charmed by his sense of humor -- and his you-know-you-like-me attitude -- Ms. Armstrong agreed to see him again. From then on, they were a pair.

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; Once Lost in Pain of Father's Death, Family Finds Hope

docs.abstract: Kari Haskell The Neediest Cases column discusses plight of Tayshah Armstrong, who is trying to recover financially and emotionally from death of Bernard Vickers, her fiancee and father of her children; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: House and Senate leaders said on Wednesday that they had reached a tentative agreement on a bill to provide prescription drug benefits to the elderly, but many Democrats spurned it, saying parts of the deal would weaken the traditional government-run Medicare program. Details of the proposed agreement were disclosed bit by bit, in a series of events that left the ultimate prospects for enactment of Medicare drug benefits uncertain.

headline.main: Tentative Medicare Pact Offers Drug Benefits to Elderly

docs.abstract: House and Senate leaders tentatively agree on bill to provide prescription drug benefits to elderly under Medicare; Democrats warn parts of deal would weaken Medicare; Republicans say they reached deal by scaling back their demands for direct competition between private health plans and traditional Medicare; Senate majority leader, Bill Frist, proposed compromise, with support from House Speaker J Dennis Hastert; deal calls for three-year test of competition in four metropolitan areas and one region of nation; elderly in those areas could stay in traditional plan, but would have to pay higher premiums if program proved more expensive than private plans; Sen John B Breaux, Democrat who took part in talks, says low-income people would be exempted from premium increases and increases for others would be limited to 10 percent a year; Sen Edward M Kennedy rejects deal, especially proposal for billions of dollars in new federal subsidies to lure private insurers into Medicare (M)
docs.snippet: House and Senate leaders said on Wednesday that they had reached a tentative agreement on a bill to provide prescription drug benefits to the elderly, but many Democrats spurned it, saying parts of the deal would weaken the traditional government-run...

docs.lead_paragraph: When Congress made it illegal 36 years ago for employers to discriminate on the basis of age, it was clear that older workers were protected from discriminatory treatment that favored those who were younger. The question in a Supreme Court argument on Wednesday was whether the Age Discrimination in Employment Act also meant the reverse: if Congress in addition meant to prohibit policies that favor older workers over younger ones. The plain language of the statute suggests one interpretation, while the context in which the law was enacted in 1967 suggests the opposite. An employer shall not discriminate against someone ''because of such individual's age,'' the law reads, without specifying ''older age'' or ''younger age.'' The law's protection begins at age 40 and has no upper limit.

headline.main: Justices Mull Twist in Law On Age Bias

docs.abstract: Supreme Court hears arguments in case testing whether law barring employers from discriminating on basis of age bars policies that favor older workers over younger ones; case involves General Dynamics's 1997 accord with United Auto Workers to let current employees who reached 50 by certain date get medical benefits in retirement, while eliminating benefit for younger workers; federal court dismissed suit by younger workers, but appeals court reinstated it; company appeal warns extending law to protect younger workers would unsettle management and labor alike (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Leaders of two of the nation's largest and most politically sophisticated unions vowed Wednesday to flood early primary states with volunteers and cash on behalf of Howard Dean, predicting that their endorsements could narrow the nine-person Democratic presidential contest. ''Not that we have asked other candidates to drop out, but we hope that this will begin to winnow the field,'' said Gerald W. McEntee, the president of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees.

headline.main: 2 Large Unions Plan a Big Push for Dean

docs.abstract: Leaders of large and politically sophisticated American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees and Service Employees International Union vow to flood early primary states with volunteers and cash for Howard Dean, predicting their endorsements could narrow Democratic presidential field; AFSCME president Gerald W McEntee pledges push in Iowa, where his union has 20,000 members; union is asking members to contribute to Dean, has budgeted $1 million for Iowa and $7.5 million for primaries; Dean hails endorsements; they will block Rep Richard A Gephardt from getting American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations endorsement; Gephardt, who has backing of 20 international unions, wins endorsement of United Auto Workers' Iowa branch; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: His wife of 37 years, Jane Gephardt, did not really want him to make another race for the presidency, and much of the conventional wisdom argued against it. This was not the political year, many of the pundits said, for a consummate insider like Representative Richard A. Gephardt, inextricably linked with every Democratic compromise, victory and defeat on Capitol Hill for the last 20 years. Indeed, to some Democrats Mr. Gephardt's support of President Bush on the war with Iraq seemed an example of all that was wrong with the party establishment.

headline.main: For Gephardt, Congress Role Is Both Platform and Hurdle

docs.abstract: Challenging Bush: first in series of articles examining lives and careers of candidates seeking Democratic presidential nomination, focuses on Rep Richard A Gephardt of Missouri; he is consummate insider inextricably linked with every Democratic compromise, victory and defeat on Capitol Hill for last 20 years; to some Democrats, his support of Pres Bush on war with Iraq is seen as example of all that is wrong with party establishment; but Gephardt is convinced that time is right for his economic message and for revival of great Democratic cause of universal health insurance; he is sure he can do better job than Pres Bush; first ran for presidential nomination in 1988; many see this as his one last chance for political vindication--of his career, of Congressional wing of party, and of set of beliefs; detailed look at his career; he was first elected to House in 1976; photos (L)
